medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient had been well until 7 years of age when diagnosed with Crohn’s disease. Approximately 5 weeks before the current admission, nonbloody diarrhea developed, occurring three or four times daily. Three weeks before admission, intermittent crampy periumbilical pain developed, radiating to both lower quadrants. Four days before admission, the symptoms worsened to include increased abdominal pain and diarrhea, decreased appetite, weight loss, arthralgias, and fever with a temperature as high as 38.9°C.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Crohn’s disease diagnosed at 7 years of age; prior treatment included omeprazole, balsalazide disodium, and azathioprine; known lactase deficiency.
medical_history.family_history: Father and sister had Crohn’s disease; father had arthritis; mother had asthma.
medical_history.social_history: Lives with mother and three siblings; attends school; allergic to tree nuts (anaphylaxis) and peanuts.
